How to Build a Sinatra App - Part 2 Rendering Views

October 27, 2024

If you don‚Äôt have your basic Sinatra app set up yet, see my previous post. Otherwise, let‚Äôs get ready to dig in and build this app!

Now let‚Äôs add some project folders and files to our app via the command line:

mkdir models && touch models/playlist.rb && touch models/pose.rb
mkdir views && mkdir views/playlists
mkdir public && touch public/application.css

Getting into ActiveHash

The data I am using in this application is static, so I‚Äôm not going to use a database. Instead, I‚Äôm going to store my data in hashes. I could use plain old regular hashes, but I am going to pull in a gem that is also available to Rails. I am doing this so I can get dot notation on my data-storing classes along with some other bells and whistles.

In the Gemfile, add the active_hash gem (check the gem on github for the latest version):

gem 'active_hash', '~> 2.3.0'

Okay while we‚Äôre here in the Gemfile, we‚Äôre also going to need a couple of Sinatra gems to help with routes. Add these to the Gemfile:

gem 'sinatra-contrib' # https://sinatrarb.com/contrib/multi_route.html
gem 'emk-sinatra-url-for' # path helpers https://github.com/emk/sinatra-url-for/

And we are going to want gem 'pry' so we can easily look at our data and do debugging, so let‚Äôs get that in there. Our Gemfile now looks like:

# Gemfile

source 'https://rubygems.org'

ruby File.read('.ruby-version').strip

gem 'sinatra'
gem 'puma'
gem 'rake'
gem 'rackup'
gem 'active_hash', '~> 2.3.0' # https://github.com/active-hash/active_hash
gem 'sinatra-contrib' # https://sinatrarb.com/contrib/multi_route.html
gem 'emk-sinatra-url-for' # path helpers https://github.com/emk/sinatra-url-for/

group :development do
  gem 'pry'
end

Save and then bundle.

And then require these gems in the app by adding them to the application.rb file. Our file now looks like:

# application.rb

# Gems
require 'sinatra'
require 'sinatra/multi_route' # from sinatra-contrib gem
require 'sinatra/url_for'
if settings.environment == :development
  require 'pry'
end

# Routes
get '/' do
  "Hello World!"
end

Okey doke, now let‚Äôs build out our models. Let‚Äôs pretend that there are 5 yoga poses, each named with a number. I‚Äôm planning to use real images and real yoga pose names in this project, but for the sake of this blog post, I‚Äôm just going to use these numbers and placeholder images. So in the models/pose.rb file, add:

# models/pose.rb

# In Sinatra, we have to require any gem we're using in a file:
require 'active_hash'

class Pose < ActiveHash::Base
  fields :name, :image_file

  # This method allows me to name a pose `:standing_forward_bend` for
  # programming convenience while displaying it as "Standing Forward
  # Bend" in the views:
  def display_name
    name.to_s.split("_").map(&:capitalize).join(" ")
  end

  self.data = [
    { id: 1, name: :one, image_file: 'https://placehold.co/100?text=One'},
    { id: 2, name: :two, image_file: 'https://placehold.co/100?text=Two'},
    { id: 3, name: :three, image_file: 'https://placehold.co/100?text=Three'},
    { id: 4, name: :four, image_file: 'https://placehold.co/100?text=Four'},
    { id: 5, name: :five, image_file: 'https://placehold.co/100?text=Five'}
  ]
end

What‚Äôs going on in that class up there? We now have pose data stored in a hash that we can access with that easy breezy dot notation just like we would a regular Ruby object. We can do:

Pose.all # => array with all the hashes
Pose.first.name # => :one
Pose.find(4).display_name # => 'Four'
Pose.find_by(name: :three) # => { id: 3, name: :three, image_file: 'https://placehold.co/100?text=Three'}
Pose.where(id: 3..) # => array with poses 3, 4, and 5

I chose to symbolize these names because I am going to be building out data in my Playlist class that references instance of this Pose class by name. I could absolutely reference them by id like a database would, but as a human, I prefer the readablity of names. In reality, yoga pose names can be long ‚Äì like ‚Äústanding forward bend‚Äù, so using a symbol like :standing_forward_bend feels more concrete to me and less prone to error (like rogue caps or spaces if I were to find_by(name: "standing forward bend")).

Now let‚Äôs get to that Playlist class in the models/playlist.rb file. Let‚Äôs pretend we have 2 playlists that we‚Äôve built from those 5 poses we built above:

# models/playlist.rb

require 'active_hash'

class Playlist < ActiveHash::Base
  fields :display_name, :poses

  self.data = [
    { id: 1, display_name: 'One Two One', poses: [
      Pose.find_by(name: :one),
      Pose.find_by(name: :two),
      Pose.find_by(name: :one)
    ]},
    { id: 2, display_name: 'One to Five', poses: [
      Pose.find_by(name: :one),
      Pose.find_by(name: :two),
      Pose.find_by(name: :three),
      Pose.find_by(name: :four),
      Pose.find_by(name: :five)
    ]},
  ]
end

In that class, I‚Äôve built 2 playlists that are consuming the Pose objects. As I said, I‚Äôm referencing them by symbolized name. Now in our app we can do things like‚Ä¶

@playlists = Playlist.all

@playlists.each do |playlist|
  playlist.display_name
end

‚Ä¶which looks eerily like what we‚Äôd do on a playlists index page, so let‚Äôs render this content on an index page!

Now, if we want to have access to this model on our index page (and we do), we‚Äôre going to need to add the models to our application.rb file. I add them after the gems and before the routes:

# application.rb

# Gems
require 'sinatra'
require 'sinatra/multi_route' # from sinatra-contrib gem
require 'sinatra/url_for'
if settings.environment == :development
  require 'pry'
end

# Models
require_relative 'models/pose'
require_relative 'models/playlist'

# Routes
get '/' do
  "Hello World!"
end

Routes that render a view file

In addition to adding the models, we‚Äôre going to need to add a new route to the application.rb:

get '/playlists' do
  @playlists = Playlist.all
  # yep, you need this weird symbolized string syntax:
  erb :'playlists/index'
end

Let‚Äôs take a look at that data before we render it in the view so we know what we have to work with. Put a binding.pry in there like this:

get '/playlists' do
  @playlists = Playlist.all
  binding.pry  # <-- stick it right here
  erb :'playlists/index'
end

Now save the file, start (or restart) your server, and go to http://localhost:4567/playlists.

In the server output, you can see the binding.pry breakpoint. Let‚Äôs play around with that @playlists object to see what ActiveHash is giving us:

@playlists.all
@playlists.first
@playlists.first.id
@playlists.first.display_name
@playlists.first.poses
@playlists.first.poses.first
@playlists.first.poses.first.id
@playlists.first.poses.first.display_name

Our hashes are acting just like Ruby objects! Pretty neat.

Okay, get out of pry with exit, then stop the server (cmd + c). Remove the binding.pry from your route. We won‚Äôt need this breakpoint anymore.

We do need a view file though, so make an index.erb (not index.html.erb) for your playlists:

<!-- views/playlists/index.erb -->

<h1>Playlists Index</h1>

<ul>
  <% @playlists.each do |playlist| %>
    <li><%= playlist.display_name %></li>
  <% end %>
</ul>

Restart your server and go back to http://localhost:4567/playlists. You should see a bulleted list of playlists. Hooray!

Side note here: Notice /playlists is not the same as /playlists/. So if you‚Äôre having trouble rendering this in the browser, this maybe why. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è The Sinatra docs for routes has more information, but I‚Äôm going to handle it in one easy step by adding this line to the application.rb file just above my first route declaration.

# application.rb

set :strict_paths, false # Normalize trailing slashes automatically

Restart the server and now you‚Äôll see that both /playlists and /playlists/ take you to that index page.

Well it‚Äôs nice that we can see the list of playlists, but it‚Äôs kind of boring if we can‚Äôt click on each playlist name to see more. So how do we get to a show page for a playlist?

Routing to a show page with an id

As you may guess, back in the application.rb, we need a new route:

# this route takes an :id param, like /playlists/42
get '/playlists/:id' do
  # and we use that param to find our specific playlist
  @playlist = Playlist.find(params[:id])
  erb :'playlists/show'
end

And a new view for the show page:

<!-- views/playlists/show.erb -->

<h1><%= @playlist.display_name %></h1>

<ul>
  <% @playlist.poses.each do |pose| %>
    <li><%= pose.display_name %></li>
  <% end %>
</ul>

Restart your server and go to http://localhost:4567/playlists/2 and you‚Äôll see our glorious show page for playlist ‚ÄúOne to Five‚Äù. And since none of us cares to memorize id numbers for random internet pages, next, we‚Äôll link to this show page from the playlists index page.

Linking from the index to the show page

In the views/playlists/index.erb file, replace this:

<li><%= playlist.display_name %></li>

with this:

<li><a href='<%= url_for "/playlists/#{playlist.id}" %>'><%= playlist.display_name %></a></li>

Is that link syntax ugly? Ohhhhh yeah it is. I haven‚Äôt looked into how to make links much prettier in Sinatra, so for now, this gets the job done.

Add a layout for consistent page design

And lastly, now that we have a few pages in our application, we‚Äôre probably going to want a nav bar and we‚Äôre probably going to want that on more than one page. We can accomplish this with an HTML layout.

Create a file called layout.erb and save it in your views folder. Fill it with basic HTML boilerplate and place a <%= yield %> where you want your page content to go.

<!-- views/layout.erb -->

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="ie=edge">
    <meta name="robots" content="noindex">
    <link href="<%= url('/application.css') %>" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
    <title>Yoga Pose Playlist</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <nav>
      <a href="<%= url_for '/' %>">Yoga Pose Playlist</a>
    </nav>

    <!-- Your page content will render here: -->
    <%= yield %>

  </body>
</html>

When you refresh your page, you‚Äôll see your new content.

Now there is no styling on that nav bar. You have a file called application.css where you can put all of the styling you‚Äôd like. I‚Äôll leave that up to you.

Our file tree looks like:

yogaposeplaylist/
- models/
  - playlist.rb
  - pose.rb
- public/
  - application.css
- views/
  - playlists/
    - index.erb
    - show.erb
  - layout.erb
- .ruby-version
- application.rb
- config.ru
- Gemfile
- Gemfile.lock
- Procfile
- README.md

But that‚Äôs it! You have all of the building blocks of basic app functionality. It‚Äôs been interesting for me to see how light and simple Sinatra feels compared to Rails ‚Äì even though I miss having link helpers and am bothered by the clutter of the application.rb file. But these are preferences built from habit and habit is always worth challenging.

I hope you‚Äôve enjoyed this foray into Sinatra and that whatever project you‚Äôre working on that lead you here inspires and challenges you in all of the good ways!

If you‚Äôd like to keep going, in this next post, I will be deploying a Sinatra app to my dyno pool in Heroku.
